A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

parent.body:
This isn’t necessarily directed at the admins, as I think they are already getting an avalanche of free advice.

They really need to have a separation of powers in terms of who set's the policy (the admins) and who enforces the policy (not the admins). This would reduce inconsistent enforcement of policies. I think they are in generally open to turning over power, as they have made Ruqqus open source on GitHub, and are willing to let someone else use the technology they developed if they drop the ball on hosting or governance.

I also would like the role of deciding on the specific implementation of larger goals to perhaps be broken into a separate role. Their goal was to have the site be more friendly towards non-political new users, but they then bungled the two steps after that. The implementation strategy of the goal of simply having an "offensive" category, and not showing those guilds; did not adequately take additional factors into consideration. They mis-stepped again by not floating such a major change to the community first, and so they were unable to get feedback and find out the degree to which users hated their idea, before rolling forward with it. This resulted in the community revolting.

In software development at companies that contain multiple departments, there are project managers/ business-developer middlemen. These people take care of consulting relevant stakeholders, floating ideas between them and ensuring smooth communication between groups, so that everyone is happy and that people actually want what is being developed. Some developers see these roles and providing no value, and dream of a world without these useless liaisons. Community management is a complex job, as is managing the various stakeholders within an organization. 

The admins are above average at doing this but are not at the level of someone who is an actual specialist, and Ruqqus needs a professional communications person in this role. Additionally, if you had a community manager who presided over this incident, you could replace them for messing it up. When the owners are doing it themselves, it is overly severe to ask for them to be replaced, but it doesn’t allow for appropriate consequences. And finally, it really isn’t the best use of the Captainmeta4 and Kek’s time to be dealing with all this community drama and communications responsibilities.

body:
I'm not sure if it's a good idea, but I think that admins should announce their plans for new features on this site before actually implementing them. For example, this category system got a lot of pushback because it didn't really work the way the users wanted it to work (I get that it was rushed though). For example, some seemed to think that all categories would be shown by default, and it turned out that some were opt-in only. It was also quite unexpected that there was (at first) no way to see posts from uncategorized guilds.

The admins say that they're listening to feedback, but their comments can be hard to find due to being hidden away in threads (you could look through captainmeta4 and kek's comment histories, but you don't know when they're responding to feedback). I'd personally like to see a place where they announce what suggestions they're considering or have accepted and which ones they have not, but I don't know how well that would work out.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

body:
I think the answer here is a 2 step solution.

1) I would ask that the devs plainly, clearly and honestly declare their intention, in terms related to what they want the end product to look like. I have suspected that their main motivation recently is to have a normie friendly front page with no "nazi shit". I very well could be wrong. So if the devs could just tell us what the intent of their rules are then we could have a shot at step 2.

2) If the community knows clearly the use case of the devs requirements then we can crowd source a solution. The community will be apart of the mechanism and will have an ability to use the voting system to promote and demote ideas. We might even find a programatically simple solution.

If the intent of the devs is something that causes an impasse with the community then we can vet the reasoning as a whole as well. The site does belong to the devs and if they simply don't want "nazi shit" on the front page, then we can have a discussion on how that doesn't resolve well with the idea of free speech. Maybe the community parts ways, maybe we find another compromise. But at least the tiring drama is over. I know I don't need to tell the devs this but remember how well things were going and how good morale was during that unbanning thread. Someone even apologized to @Snappy as inappropriate as that seems ;).

These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

post.body:
The impression that the admins have let develop upon Ruqqus users is that the admins strongly dislike the Ruqqus userbase, feel the need to hide the userbase in order to appease a base more similar to Reddit's, and would ultimately like to replace the current userbase. A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

body:
Honestly, Ruqqus is in the position where I'll use it because it lacks better alternatives (no activity, even stricter, or corporate manipulation), but I'm willing to move to any alternatives that looks promising to what I want - actually something that followed the Ruqqus original claims of "as long as its legal its welcome" and the activity and UI to keep it alive and functional would be enough. It could have been Ruqqus if they didn't abandon that.

But for what's pushing me away? I came here to avoid supporting censorship and corporate manipulation first, talk hobbies second, and talk general topics third.

Censorship: I think the exiles users and kicks posts are getting from official guilds are a bit... much, as I said in a previous comment, it comes off more like the administration either wants to hide criticism or can't handle it. The fact this post hasn't been kicked as of the time I was reading it is, at least, somewhat reassuring that they may be catching on that they pushed too far.

Hobbies: Three issues here. First, a lot of good prominent hobby users got ran off by witch hunting, which usually seems to follow from Discord drama. Second, the loli-ban does more to scare off the anime fandom then you think (Imagine you don't even like loli, but you post something you'd never consider loli. And then you find out the admins *do* consider it loli. This isn't something you can get an obvious line for not crossing, unless they limit their posting to tall wrinkly grannies), and anime and gaming are the gateways to hobby topics on alt tech, due to being heavier targets of censorship and controversy. Third, its not uncommon for hobby guilds to be carried by one poster, with many people lurking in the comments - this poses an issue as it means only one person leads the discussion. Obviously, this last one is something only the community (and that includes myself) can solve by having passion to share, or something they consider worthwhile for others to see.

General: I'm not a fan of having to enable all categories to see *everything*. Call me crazy, but it might be nice if there was just a quick button to swap between everything and your selected categories (or possible multiple pre-sets of category selections!). Other than that, most of my time here on Ruqqus is now on "general conversation", the lowest value on my list.

post.body:
The impression that the admins have let develop upon Ruqqus users is that the admins strongly dislike the Ruqqus userbase, feel the need to hide the userbase in order to appease a base more similar to Reddit's, and would ultimately like to replace the current userbase. A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

body:
It is pointless to make demands or pose questions, as that does not alter the truth of reality and is doubtful to alter any admin opinions.

Given past actions and the intent behind them it is doubtless to me that if the admins could swap the userbase, they would. Quite frankly, that's true of any site, as we are a minority and more money comes from the majority.

As such, when it comes to a point that us cultural contrarians are eventually outnumbered, they will have no further need for us.

Any words spoken at this point will only be appeasement, as without us as userbase there is no contribution. Based on downvotes gathered from operation sneed, there's 25, TWENTY FIVE, active (voting) users in US timezones that oppose our contrarian efforts, and 50-100 active (voting) contrarians. These numbers are pitiful, especially compared with the supposed 3k general members.

Anyway, we'll get kicked off this site eventually, or maybe we'll stick around. If not this, there's poal. If not poal, something else will come around. Quite frankly, I look forward to the day that all platforms are gone, and the faster that day comes the faster somebody might do something about the situation. As it stands, with every tick of the clock we get fucked by one additional thrust from the system cementing its grip.

post.body:
The impression that the admins have let develop upon Ruqqus users is that the admins strongly dislike the Ruqqus userbase, feel the need to hide the userbase in order to appease a base more similar to Reddit's, and would ultimately like to replace the current userbase. A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

The impression that the admins have let develop upon Ruqqus users is that the admins strongly dislike the Ruqqus userbase, feel the need to hide the userbase in order to appease a base more similar to Reddit's, and would ultimately like to replace the current userbase. A significant portion of the userbase has also expressed that they feel like they no longer know the admins' intentions for the site.

Furthermore, Ruqqus users feel that their thoughts, opinions, and suggestions are often overlooked and disregarded in favor of those from Ruqqus Discord members. These same Discord members seem to differ in usability significant ways from the average Ruqqus user and have been documented expressing open disdain for the current userbase time and time again. It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

parent.body:
I'm not sure if it's a good idea, but I think that admins should announce their plans for new features on this site before actually implementing them. For example, this category system got a lot of pushback because it didn't really work the way the users wanted it to work (I get that it was rushed though). For example, some seemed to think that all categories would be shown by default, and it turned out that some were opt-in only. It was also quite unexpected that there was (at first) no way to see posts from uncategorized guilds.

The admins say that they're listening to feedback, but their comments can be hard to find due to being hidden away in threads (you could look through captainmeta4 and kek's comment histories, but you don't know when they're responding to feedback). I'd personally like to see a place where they announce what suggestions they're considering or have accepted and which ones they have not, but I don't know how well that would work out.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

It is pointless to make demands or pose questions, as that does not alter the truth of reality and is doubtful to alter any admin opinions.

Given past actions and the intent behind them it is doubtless to me that if the admins could swap the userbase, they would. Quite frankly, that's true of any site, as we are a minority and more money comes from the majority.

As such, when it comes to a point that us cultural contrarians are eventually outnumbered, they will have no further need for us.

Any words spoken at this point will only be appeasement, as without us as userbase there is no contribution. Based on downvotes gathered from operation sneed, there's 25, TWENTY FIVE, active (voting) users in US timezones that oppose our contrarian efforts, and 50-100 active (voting) contrarians. These numbers are pitiful, especially compared with the supposed 3k general members.

Anyway, we'll get kicked off this site eventually, or maybe we'll stick around. If not this, there's poal. If not poal, something else will come around. Quite frankly, I look forward to the day that all platforms are gone, and the faster that day comes the faster somebody might do something about the situation. As it stands, with every tick of the clock we get fucked by one additional thrust from the system cementing its grip.

parent.body:
This isn’t necessarily directed at the admins, as I think they are already getting an avalanche of free advice.

They really need to have a separation of powers in terms of who set's the policy (the admins) and who enforces the policy (not the admins). This would reduce inconsistent enforcement of policies. I think they are in generally open to turning over power, as they have made Ruqqus open source on GitHub, and are willing to let someone else use the technology they developed if they drop the ball on hosting or governance.

I also would like the role of deciding on the specific implementation of larger goals to perhaps be broken into a separate role. Their goal was to have the site be more friendly towards non-political new users, but they then bungled the two steps after that. The implementation strategy of the goal of simply having an "offensive" category, and not showing those guilds; did not adequately take additional factors into consideration. They mis-stepped again by not floating such a major change to the community first, and so they were unable to get feedback and find out the degree to which users hated their idea, before rolling forward with it. This resulted in the community revolting.

In software development at companies that contain multiple departments, there are project managers/ business-developer middlemen. These people take care of consulting relevant stakeholders, floating ideas between them and ensuring smooth communication between groups, so that everyone is happy and that people actually want what is being developed. Some developers see these roles and providing no value, and dream of a world without these useless liaisons. Community management is a complex job, as is managing the various stakeholders within an organization. 

The admins are above average at doing this but are not at the level of someone who is an actual specialist, and Ruqqus needs a professional communications person in this role. Additionally, if you had a community manager who presided over this incident, you could replace them for messing it up. When the owners are doing it themselves, it is overly severe to ask for them to be replaced, but it doesn’t allow for appropriate consequences. And finally, it really isn’t the best use of the Captainmeta4 and Kek’s time to be dealing with all this community drama and communications responsibilities.

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

body:
I think it's a bit much probably for any one user to make "demands", but I think to strongly encourage or have a wish list of some of those sound like good ideas. But for me I think this can be resolved without an all or nothing on having those met. I don't have demands, I just want to be a part of the conversation on site changes and respected. I particularly think it would be good for them to talk more on ruqqus about sitewide plans, there's already been some good feedback in this thread. I think sometimes it might seem like a thankless task, but I appreciate Ruqqus in a lot of ways and am thankful for the time and energy that they have poured into it.

It doesn't help that captainmeta4 has been documented telling users that their suggestions don't matter in his usual condescending and dismissive tone (feel free to post that screenshot if you have it on hand).

Common words to describe the Ruqqus userbase on the Ruqqus Discord server are "Nazi" "Retarded" "Schizo" "Stupid" "Delusional" "Conspiracy Theorist" among more and they usually conflate all of the base with a user or a group of users they don't like. A lot of people like to clean up the phrasing when talking about admin opinions and Ruqqus Discord, but I don't.

Your concerns are often dismissed on the basis of this name-calling and strawman-ing regardless of topic and regardless of how respectfully you phrase them. I among others ( @SamRF @stars_in_blue_major) very recently went on Ruqqus Discord and asked for admins to formally address your concerns about the admins' views of the base and about the schism between Ruqqus Discord and the Ruqqus userbase. We were met with more of the same. From that "discussion" it is apparent that the admins are "done" with the userbase and would rather just ignore it than deal with "schizos" who "don't listen" and are now calling them mean names.

The Ruqqus Admins fail to acknowledge that the base has gotten to the point of open protest, name-calling, and speculation specifically because of the awful public relations and inability to at least feign impartiality on their part. It is not normal for admins to have such a heated relationship with it's userbase, yet instead of acknowledge the part they've played, they place all of the blame on you for being "nazis" or otherwise undesirables.

Quiet honestly, their behavior tells me don't have what it takes to be business leaders and should've stuck to programming if they can't be bothered to come up with a marketing or business plan for their product, can't definitively communicate their intentions for the site, can't avoid effectively splitting the stakeholders of the site into opposing teams, and can't be assed to understand or even cordially communicate with their userbase about anything other than updates. They'd be better off if they gave the CEO position to someone who can actually behave like and perform CEO duties; maybe that person would've hired an actual marketing and PR person.

___________________

**BUT**, I think the thing that we all have and common and the reason that we are all still here is because we *want* Ruqqus to succeed and don't want it to just be another Reddit.

So, how about we try to mend the relationship by laying out the questions we need answers to in order to continue to be supporters of the platform and the steps that need to be taken in order to restore user confidence in the dev team.

**Post your questions and suggestions in the comments and I will select the best ones ( most relevant to the topics of** *attitudes toward the userbase, long-term intentions for the site,* **and** *restoring user confidence* **) to the final Reconciliation Proposal to the Ruqqus Admins.**

@NothinWrong had some good ones to start off. I'll add to them as they come in.

**Questions**

* *Do the admins support the actions of users to drive away right-wingers, "nazis" and/or Voat users?*

* *If not, will users who have done this face consequences for these actions? And, how will this be prevented in the future?*

* *Do you feel having less right-wing users is beneficial for Ruqqus and/or your profits?*

* *Does Ruqqus TOS allow users to set up offsite servers to brigade users and manipulate the contents of the front page?*

* *Will Ruqqus Admins maintain their commitment to free speech, privacy, transparency, and fairness as well as they can, even when you receive either public or private feedback against doing so?*

* *Can the admins make a commitment to spending more time interacting with users on Ruqqus than interacting with them on offsite chat platforms?*

* *Plainly, clearly and honestly; what are your intentions for Ruqqus as a platform and what does the end product look like?*

**Demands**

* *Delete the Ruqqus Discord server and set up an uncensored chat on an uncensored service where pro-free-speech people can participate, if an offsite chat system is needed.*

* *Stop posting ban notices to off-site chat participants because that enables them to siege and subvert guilds they dislike before actual guild members.*

* *Unban and stop banning people from Ruqqus relevant, admin run guilds. Stop kicking on-topic posts.*

* *End the favoritism of offsite chat participant feedback and suggestions over Ruqqus user feedback and suggestions.*

* *Prioritize free speech settings and features over filtering and censorship features.*

* *Stop giving passes and justification to offsite chat participants that regular Ruqqus users don't get.*

* *Stop dismissing your own (admin) mistakes as minor and then disparaging people for reacting to them.*

* *Do not participate in attempts to troll or demean Ruqqus users.*

* *Communicate all information relevant to regular users, guildmasters, and any other role that may be created in the future through Ruqqus.com at least 24 hours prior to announcing it on offsite chat platforms.*

* *End all categorization based on "offense" and do not shadowban uncategorized guilds.*

* *End snap decision/ instant banning and offer 2 official warnings prior to ban.*

* *Do not self-appoint to guildmaster or any other roles in order to change guild settings.*

* *Add a publicly viewable appeal process for banned and exiled users.*

* *Explicitly state all users who have the ability to write code for Ruqqus and their privileges relative to the average Ruqqus user in the +RuqqusAdmin guild description and on the Ruqqus corporate website.*

* *Hire someone who is not any of you to manage Marketing & Community Relations for Ruqqus.*

* *Enagage in a UX deisgn process and announce and receive community feedback on plans for new features as posts in a designated guild prior to implementation.*

* *Create a separation of powers between those who set policy and those who enforce policy.*

Before you tell me this is hyperbole, this is exactly what happened to Voat and Gab in the past. Also, Ruqqus was deplatformed some months ago by Patreon.
